summary: This is a Department of Justice afternoon news digest from April 14, 2020, covering various legal and COVID-19 related headlines. It includes a brief update on a Jeffrey Epstein victim losing her bid to challenge his 2007 non-prosecution agreement and a note about Harvard professor Lawrence Lessig withdrawing a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times related to its coverage of Epstein.

persons.name: Courtney Wild
persons.context: A Jeffrey Epstein victim who lost her bid to challenge the non-prosecution deal Epstein made with federal prosecutors in Florida in 2007.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier and registered sex offender whose 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Florida federal prosecutors is referenced in a legal update.

persons.name: Lawrence Lessig
persons.context: A Harvard Law School professor who withdrew a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times concerning an article about his views toward Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Wild is identified as a victim of Epstein, and she filed a legal challenge to his non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Court denies Epstein victim's challenge to NPA
events.description: A court ruled against Courtney Wild's bid to challenge the non-prosecution agreement Jeffrey Epstein made with federal prosecutors in Florida in 2007.

events.title: Lawrence Lessig withdraws defamation lawsuit
events.description: Harvard professor Lawrence Lessig withdrew his defamation lawsuit against The New York Times over a September 2019 article concerning his views on Jeffrey Epstein donations.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors in Florida, allowing him to avoid federal sex trafficking charges and plead guilty to lesser state charges.

keyFacts: On April 14, 2020, a court denied Jeffrey Epstein victim Courtney Wild's attempt to challenge his 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Florida federal prosecutors.
The non-prosecution agreement allowed Epstein to avoid federal sex trafficking charges and instead plead guilty to state charges including soliciting a minor for prostitution.
Harvard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig withdrew a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times related to its coverage of his views on accepting donations from Jeffrey Epstein.
